case_name: Civil Appeals Nos. 474 to 501, 503 to 505, 508 to 512, 514 and 515 of 1959

facts.text: There are 38 civil appeals numbered 474 to 501, 503 to 505, 508 to 512, 514 and 515 of 1959.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION civil Appeals Nos. 474 to 501, 503 to 505, 508 to 512, 514 and 515 of 1959.

facts.text: Appeals are from Orissa High Court judgment and orders dated November 28, 1956 in O.J.C. No. 213 of 1955 and dated December 4, 1956 in other O.J.C.s of 1955.

anchor.surface_text: Appeals from the judgment and orders dated November, 28, 1956, in O. J. C. No. 213 of 1955 and dated December 4, 1956, of the Orissa High Court in O. J. C. Nos. 214 to 216, 218, 236 to 241, 244 to 248, 251, 261 to 264, 268, 269, 271, 279 to 282, 304 to 306, 318, 323, 324, 353, 357, 363 and 372 of 1955.

facts.text: Orissa High Court dismissed 42 petitions under Article 226 filed by present appellants and some others.

anchor.surface_text: These are 38 appeals against the judgment and orders of the High Court of Orissa dated November 28, 1956, by which 42 petitions under Art. 226 of the Constitution filed by the present appellants and some others were dismissed.

facts.text: High Court certified the cases as fit for appeal to Supreme Court under Article 132.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court certified the cases as fit for appeal to this Court under Art. 132 1  of the Constitution.

facts.text: Appellants are holders of pre-settlement minor inams in the State of Orissa.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants are holders of pre-settlement minor inams in the State of Orissa.

facts.text: Grants were made at different times for different lands for performance of services of deities, classed as Devadayam grants, minor inams comprising certain lands with melwaram and kudiwaram rights.

anchor.surface_text: Their grants art, different both in regard to the time when they were made and the lands involved in them. They were made for performance of services of deities and were classed as Devadayam grants in the revenue papers. The grants in all these cases were number of whole villages but of certain lands and hence their classification as minor inams, and they companyprised both the melwaram and kudiwaram rights in the lands.

facts.text: Orissa State Government issued Notification No.4971-XV--9154-E.A. dated July 15, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: involving the companysideration whether Notification No.4971-XV--9154-E.A. dated July 15, 1955, issued by the Orissa State Government,

facts.text: Orissa Estates Abolition Act, 1951 (Act 1 of 1952) abolished all estates of intermediaries, which vested in Government on notification.

anchor.surface_text: and the Orissa Estates Abolition Act, 1951  Act 1 of 1952  as amended by the Orissa Estate Abolition  Amendment  Act, 1954  Act XXVII of 1954  were respectively beyond the companypetence of the State and the Orissa State Legislature. By the original Act, all estates of the intermediaries were abolished, and on a numberification by the Government, such,estates vested in Government.

facts.text: Orissa Estates Abolition Amendment Act, 1954 (Act XXVII of 1954) widened definition of estate to cover minor inams.

anchor.surface_text: By the amending, Act, the definition of estate was widened to companyer even such, minor inams, and then the impugned numberification was issued.

facts.text: Bill for original Act introduced on January 17, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: The Bill resulting in the original Act was introduced on January 17, 1950,

facts.text: Original Act passed by Legislative Assembly on September 28, 1951.

anchor.surface_text: and the Act was passed by the Legislative Assembly September 28, 1951

facts.text: President gave assent to original Act on January 23, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: It was reserved for the companysideration of the president, Who gave his assent on January 23, 1952.

facts.text: Amending Act of 1954 was reserved for consideration of President and assented to by him.

anchor.surface_text: The amending Act was also reserved for the companysideration of the President and was assented to by him.

facts.text: Constitution First Amendment Act, 1951 enacted on June 18, 1951, inserting Article 31A with retrospective operation.

anchor.surface_text: On June 18, 1951, before the Act was passed by the Legislative Assembly, the Constitution  First Amendment  Act, 1951 bad been enacted, and Art. 31A inserted with retrospective operation in the Constitution.

facts.text: Appellants contend that original Act and amending Act were beyond competence of State Legislature.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant companytend that the original Act and the amending Act were, jointly or severally beyond the companypetence ,of the State Legislature and that the numberification above mentioned was void without any effect.

facts.text: Appellants contend minor inams not covered by original definition of estate, only whole inam villages per Madras Estates Land Act.

anchor.surface_text: The second argument is that the word estate as. defined in s.2 g  before its amendment did. number apply to pre-,settlement minor inams of lands as it applied only to an inam estate, and an inam estate bad the meaning which the definition of estate had in the, Madras Estates Land Act., viz., only whole inam villages.

facts.text: Supreme Court judgment delivered on August 22, 1961 by HIDAYATULLAH, J.

anchor.surface_text: 1961. August 22. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by HIDAYATULLAH, J.-

facts.text: Definition of estate in original Act referred to general registers and included inam estate or part.

anchor.surface_text: In the Act, before its amendment in 1954, estate was defined as follows 2 g  Estate means any and held by an intermediary and included under one entry in any of the general registers of revenue-paying lands and revenue-free lands prepared and maintained under the law for the time being in force by the companylector of district , and includes revenue free-lands number entered in any register and all classes of tenures or under tenures or an inam estate or part of an estate

facts.text: Amending Act substituted new definition of estate including any jagir, inam, or muafi or other similar grant.

anchor.surface_text: By the amending act of 1954 this definition was substituted by another which, read 2 g  Estate includes apart of an estate and means any land held by or vested in an intermediary and included under one entry in any revenue roll or any of the general registers of revenue-paying lands and revenue free lands, prepared and maintained under the law relating to land revenue for the time be- ing in force or under any rule, order, custom or usage having the force of law, and includes revenue-free lands number entered in any register or revenue-roll and all classes of tenures or under tenures and any jagir, inam, or muafi or other similar grant.

facts.text: Section 3 of amending Act declares that lands previously covered by old definitions continue to be covered despite widening.

anchor.surface_text: In the original Act, a provision was inserted by s.3 of the amending Act to the following effect For the purpose of removal of all doubts it is declared that- such lands and such rights in relation thereto and such persons who hold such lands and such rights as were heretofore companyered by the definitions of the words estate and Intermediary in the Orissa Estates Abolition Act, 1951, shall number cease to be so companyered merely on the ground that by virtue of the provisions of this Act the said definitions have been amended and widened in scope.

facts.text: Estate defined in Madras Estates Land Act, 1908 as any inam village granted, confirmed or recognised by Government.

anchor.surface_text: To companyplete the survey of the provisions which we way have to refer to in this judgment, we first set down the definition of estate as given in the Madras Estates Land Act, 1908, which was applied to Orissa. Section 3 2  d  of that Act defined estate as Any inam village, of which the grant has been made, companyfirmed or recognised by the Government,

facts.text: Court holds that amending Act is protected under Article 31A as it extends compulsory acquisition to new properties with President's assent.

anchor.surface_text: The first argument is clearly untenable. ... The assent of the President to the amending Act thus brought in the protection of Art. 31A as a necessary companysequence.

facts.text: Minor inams are covered by the widened definition of estate including any inam.

anchor.surface_text: The extended definition in the Constitution and a similar extended definition in the Act thus exclude resort to the general definition clause in s.2 q , of the Abolition let and the definition of estate in the Madras, Estates Land Act. The definition of estate introduced by the amending Act is sufficiently wide to companyer such minor inams,

facts.text: Notification under Section 3(1) of Abolition Act declares estates vested in State free from encumbrances.

anchor.surface_text: Section 3 of the Abolition Act says 3 1  The State Government may, from time to time by numberification, declare that the estate specified in the numberification has passed to and become vested in the State free from all encumbrances.

issues.text: whether Notification No.4971-XV--9154-E.A. dated July 15, 1955, issued by the Orissa State Government, and the Orissa Estates Abolition Act, 1951 as amended by the Orissa Estate Abolition Amendment Act, 1954 were respectively beyond the competence of the State and the Orissa State Legislature

anchor.surface_text: It is number necessary to refer to these cases separately, since a single argument was addressed before us involving the companysideration whether Notification No.4971-XV--9154-E.A. dated July 15, 1955, issued by the Orissa State Government, and the Orissa Estates Abolition Act, 1951  Act 1 of 1952  as amended by the Orissa Estate Abolition  Amendment  Act, 1954  Act XXVII of 1954  were respectively beyond the companypetence

issues.text: whether the benefit of Art. 31A is available to the amending Act which enlarged the definition of estate, or only to the original Act

anchor.surface_text: The contention of the appellants is really twofold. The first argument is that the benefit of Art. 31A might have been available to the original Act, as it was a law for the companypulsory acquisition of property for public purposes but number to the amending Act, which was number such, a law but only amended a previous law by, enlarging the definition of estate.

issues.text: whether the definition of 'estate' in s.2(g) of the Orissa Estates Abolition Act (pre and post amendment) includes pre-settlement minor inams of lands
whether the notification issued under s.3 of the Orissa Estates Abolition Act is valid

anchor.surface_text: Section 3 of the Abolition Act says 3 1  The State Government may, from time to time by numberification, declare that the estate specified in the numberification has passed to and become vested in the State free from all encumbrances. ... the numberification was thus valid, if the law was valid.

issues.text: whether the ejusdem generis rule applies to the definition of 'estate' in Art.31A(2)(a) and s.2(g) of the Act so as to exclude minor inams

anchor.surface_text: Learned companynsel for the appellants also urged, through somewhat faintly, that the ejusdem generis rule should be applied to the definition of ,estate in Art. 31A 2  a  as also to the companyresponding new definition in the Abolition Act.

arguments.claim: The original Act and the amending Act were, jointly or severally, beyond the competence of the State Legislature and the notification was void without any effect.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant contend that the original Act and the amending Act were, jointly or severally beyond the competence ,of the State Legislature and that the notification above mentioned was void without any effect.

arguments.court_reasoning: Protected by Article 31A due to President's assent; definitions cover minor inams.

arguments.claim: The benefit of Art. 31A is available to the original Act as a law for compulsory acquisition but not to the amending Act which only enlarged the definition of estate.

anchor.surface_text: The contention of the appellants is really twofold. The first argument is that the benefit of Art. 31A might have been available to the original Act,. as it was a law for the compulsory acquisition of property for public purposes but not to the amending Act, which was not such, a law but only amended a previous law by, enlarging the definition of estate.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: intermediaries and number inams which it did. Section 3 of the Abolition Act says 3 1  The State Government may, from time to time by numberification,

arguments.court_reasoning: President's assent to amending Act extends protection of Art. 31A to new categories of property like minor inams; legislative practice supports this.

arguments.claim: The word 'estate' as defined in s.2(g) before amendment did not apply to pre-settlement minor inams as it applied only to an inam estate meaning whole inam villages per Madras Estates Land Act via s.2(q).

anchor.surface_text: The second argument is that the word estate as. defined in s.2 g  before its amendment did. not apply to pre-,settlement minor inams of lands as it applied only to an inam estate, and an inam estate had the meaning which the definition of estate had in the, Madras Estates Land Act., viz., only whole inam villages.

arguments.court_reasoning: Amended definition explicitly includes 'any inam'; s.2(q) inapplicable where term defined in Act; original definition includes 'inam estate or part' via registers.

arguments.claim: The ejusdem generis rule should be applied to the definition of 'estate' in Art. 31A(2)(a) and corresponding new definition in the Abolition Act to exclude minor inams.
arguments.court_reasoning: Ejusdem generis applies to general words like 'other similar grant' but not specific terms like 'inam'; minor inams are inams regardless of size.

arguments.claim: President's assent to the amending Act brings in the protection of Art. 31A as it extends compulsory acquisition to new properties like minor inams.

anchor.surface_text: The first argument is clearly untenable. ... The assent of the President to the amending Act thus brought in the protection of Art. 31A as a necessary consequence.

arguments.claim: The amended definition of 'estate' in s.2(g) is sufficiently wide to cover minor inams as it includes 'any jagir, inam, or muafi or other similar grant'.

anchor.surface_text: By the amending act of 1954 this definition was substituted by another which, read 2 g  Estate includes apart of an estate and means any land held by or vested in an intermediary ... The definition of estate introduced by the amending Act is sufficiently wide to cover such minor inams,

arguments.claim: s.2(q) does not apply because 'estate' is defined in the Act itself; no need to resort to tenancy laws or Madras Estates Land Act definition.
Original s.2(g) definition covers minor inams as 'inam estate or part of an estate' included under revenue registers.

anchor.surface_text: In the Act, before its amendment in 1954, estate was defined as follows 2 g  Estate means any and held by an intermediary and included under one entry in any of the general registers ... or an inam estate or part of an estate

arguments.claim: s.3 of amending Act clarifies that lands covered by old definitions continue to be covered despite widening; adds but does not subtract.

anchor.surface_text: In the original Act, a provision was inserted by s.3 of the amending Act to the following effect For the purpose of removal of all doubts it is declared that- such lands ... shall not cease to be so covered merely on the ground that ... definitions have been amended and widened in scope.

arguments.court_reasoning: The meaning of the last provision is clear. It takes away nothing from the ambit of the old definition, but only adds thereto.

arguments.claim: Notification under s.3(1) is valid if the law is valid, vesting estates free from encumbrances.

anchor.surface_text: Section 3 of the Abolition Act says 3 1  The State Government may, from time to time by notification, declare that the estate specified in the notification has passed to and become vested in the State free from all encumbrances. ... the notification was thus valid, if the law was valid.

arguments.claim: Distinction of no intermediaries or holding both melwaram and kudiwaram irrelevant as law targets estates/inams directly.

holdings.text: The first argument that the benefit of Art. 31A is not available to the amending Act is clearly untenable; President's assent brings protection of Art. 31A.

anchor.surface_text: The first argument is clearly untenable. It assumes that the benefit of Art.31A is only available to those laws which by themselves provide for compulsory acquisition of property for public purposes and not to laws amending such laws, the assent of the President notwithstanding. This mea

holdings.reasoning_summary: Amending Act extends original law to new properties; President assents to extension as law for compulsory acquisition; legislative practice supports.

holdings.text: Original Act and amending Act are within competence of State Legislature; protected by Art. 31A due to President's assent.

anchor.surface_text: The contention of the appellants is really twofold. The first argument is that the benefit of Art. 31A might have been available to the original Act, as it was a law for the compulsory acquisition of property for public purposes but not to the amending Act, which was not such, a law

holdings.reasoning_summary: Assent to amending Act in relation to original Act extends protection; rejects need for repassage of entire law.

holdings.text: Amended definition of 'estate' in s.2(g) sufficiently wide to cover minor inams as it includes any jagir, inam, or muafi or other similar grant.

anchor.surface_text: The extended definition in the Constitution and a similar extended definition in the Act thus exclude resort to the general definition clause in s.2 q , of the Abolition let and the definition of estate in the Madras, Estates Land Act. The definition of estate introduced by the amend

holdings.reasoning_summary: Explicit inclusion of 'any inam'; follows constitutional definition in Art.31A; s.2(q) inapplicable where defined in Act.

holdings.text: s.2(q) does not apply to 'estate' as it is defined in the Act itself; no resort to Madras Estates Land Act or tenancy laws.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Specific definition prevails over general interpretation clause; minor inams fit within defined terms.

holdings.text: s.3 of amending Act adds to scope of old definition without subtracting; lands previously covered remain covered.

anchor.surface_text: In the original Act, a provision was inserted by s.3 of the amending Act to the following effect For the purpose of removal of all doubts it is declared that- such lands and such rights in relation thereto and such persons who hold such lands and such rights as were heretofore cove

holdings.reasoning_summary: Clear language of removal of doubts clause; new definition plainly adds.

holdings.text: Ejusdem generis rule does not apply to specific term 'inam' in Art.31A(2)(a) and s.2(g); applies only to 'other similar grant'.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Rule limits general terms by preceding specifics; 'inam' is specific, not general.

holdings.text: Notification under s.3(1) valid as law valid, vesting estates in State free from encumbrances.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows from valid definition and law; protected from fundamental rights challenge by Art.31A.

holdings.text: Minor inams are estates despite not whole villages, no intermediaries, or holding both melwaram and kudiwaram; law targets inams directly.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Constitution and Act define broadly; abolishes inams, not just intermediaries.
